speaker: Frasier
text: Lilian, the next time your perfectionist tendencies drive you to distraction, just remember this quotation from Henry James:  "Excellence does not require perfection."

speaker: Lillian
text: [_voice over_]  That's very helpful.  Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Or is it "demand"?  Hmm... "require", "demand"  "Excellence does not require perfection." "Excellence does not demand perfection."

speaker: Roz
text: Aren't they the same thing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course not, Roz!  Shush!  "Excellence"..."demand", "require", "demand", "require"...Oohh!  Or is it "mandate"?

speaker: Lillian
text: [_v.o._]  I really have to go now.  [_There is a click and a dial tone as she disconnects._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well, it doesn't really matter, anyway, does it? Meantime, Seattle, this is Doctor Frasier Crane, wishing you good day OH!  It's "require", it is "require"!  [_he laughs victoriously_]   And good mental health.  [_He goes off the air and Roz comes over and holds something out._]

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, would you please give this to Freddie for me?  It's for his spelling bee tomorrow.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_taking it_]  Roz, it's not a spelling bee, it's the National Championship.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh.  Ooh, when's Lilith coming in?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_rising_]  Actually, she's not coming in, she'll be watching the competition ion from home.  Her victory dance at the state finals earned her a long overdue suspension.  So, what is this anyway?

speaker: Roz
text: It's a flattened penny.  I found it at the railroad tracks once when I was going through a really bad time.  But as soon as I picked it up, I started getting lucky.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, so that's where it all started.

speaker: Roz
text: No.  Why are you turning a nice gesture into something dirty?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, Roz.  I know it didn't bring you that kind of luck.

speaker: Roz
text: Thank you.  [_She heads for her side as he grabs his briefcase._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Because that would be one tired penny.  [_He hurries out as she glares at him.  Fade out._]   [_Fade in.  Frasier is sitting down.  Sitting on dining chairs facing him, are Freddie, Martin and Eddie._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Eddie Crane, from Seattle, your word is "woof".  [_Eddie barks.  Frasier rolls his eyes, then Martin talks out of the corner of his mouth for him._]

speaker: Martin
text: W-O-O-F.  [_He nudges Eddie, who barks again._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Very good.  Frederick Crane, from Massachusetts, your word is "onomatopoeia"  [_Freddie stands up and takes a breath._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Wrong.  Where are your knees?  I want to see spelling knees.

speaker: Freddie
text: Oh, yeah, right.

speaker: Frasier
text: The last thing I want is you passing out on stage because of locked knees.

speaker: Freddie
text: I know.  Allison Sharpe, the "'Frisco Fainter".

speaker: Frasier
text: She went down like a sack of hammers.  All right now, go to the hallway mirror and look at your form.  [_Freddie walks off and Martin gets up._]

speaker: Martin
text: Aren't you two going a little overboard with this?  The drills, the stance, the spelling diet...  [_He sets back in his chair._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, Freddie really wants to win this competition, I'm doing my best to help him.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you shouldn't over train him.  He needs to have some fun.

speaker: Frasier
text: I told him he could bring his clarinet!  [_off Martin's look_] All right, I'll talk to him.  [_Freddie comes back in._]

speaker: Freddie
text: Thanks, Dad, I think I got my stance down now.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_rising_]  Good boy.  Frederick, have a seat for a minute. There's something I want to tell you.  [_Freddie sits back down in his chair, Frasier sits beside him._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, I don't want you to get consumed by this spelling bee thing, all right?  It's not important if you're a good speller or the best speller.  The important thing is that you have fun.  Okay?

speaker: Freddie
text: Okay, Dad.  You know what would be really fun?

speaker: Frasier
text: What's that?

speaker: Freddie
text: Kicking butt in the spelling bee.  [_Frasier laughs and Freddie moves over to the couch as Niles and Daphne come in the front._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello all.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, I'm afraid I've got some bad news.  I could only get two tickets for the spelling bee competition tomorrow.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, that's a shame.  But we'll be there in spirit.  It's probably just as well considering how emotional I get watching children compete.  I keep thinking how much it means to them.  Like the little girl who studies over candle light while her father's down at the local pub, drinking away the money for the light bill.  Or the little girl on the school bus who pretends not to see her father waving at her from the pub.  Then there's the little girl who thinks that by doing well she can grow up, purchase the local pub, and turn it into a circus so her father can keep his promise.  [_She bursts into tears and runs off to her room._]

speaker: Niles
text: We had a little wine at lunch.  Don't worry about the tickets. While I certainly would have gone to support Freddie, I have to admit wasn't looking forward to being back in that environment.  [_to Freddie_]  Don't get sidetracked by all the glitz and glamour of the bee.  Spelling well is its own reward.  [_He heads off to Daphne's room._]

speaker: Freddie
text: What was that about?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, your Uncle Niles has a painful history with spelling bees.

speaker: Freddie
text: Really?  Was he any good?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, one of the best to ever compete.

speaker: Freddie
text: Better than you Dad?

speaker: Frasier
text: Son, as good as I was, my spelling couldn't compare with Niles'.  He was right up there with the likes of William Karek from Akron, and that Peterson girl from Omaha.

speaker: Martin
text: Except your uncle was even younger.  Some people thought he wasn't ready, that it was a mistake to bring him up to The Show right of elementary school, but he made it.  All the way to the last word.

speaker: Freddie
text: What happened?

speaker: Frasier
text: He didn't even try to spell it.  He just stood there for a moment, then turned and walked off the stage.

speaker: Martin
text: He was immediately disqualified and he never competed again.

speaker: Freddie
text: Never?

speaker: Martin
text: Sure, he'd spell now and again.  But only to help you out and you had to really need it, 'cause he could spot a set-up a mile away.

speaker: Freddie
text: Wow. Sounds to me like he choked.

speaker: Martin
text: Choked...  OR, was he the victim of an elaborate conspiracy?

speaker: Freddie
text: Really?  [_Martin looks behind him._]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I thought I heard him comin' down the hall.  He choked.  [_Fade out._]   [_Fade in.  There are only four students left on the stage, including Freddie.  A young man is at the microphone, the moderator, Dr. Gaston, is at a podium._]

speaker: Contestant
text: "Logorrhea".  Um, can I have a definition?

speaker: Martin
text: Uh-oh, always a bad sign.

speaker: Gaston
text: Excessive use of words.

speaker: Contestant
text: L-O-G-O-R-H-E-A, "logorrhea".  [_A buzzer sounds._]

speaker: Gaston
text: I'm sorry, that's incorrect.  [_The boy leaves the stage._]

speaker: Frasier
text: So long, home school.

speaker: Gaston
text: And that completes the tenth round.  We'll begin round eleven of the National Spelling Championship after a five minute intermission.  [_The audience and contestants get up and Frasier waves Freddie over._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Freddie, you're doing great, son, great!

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, you got it made.  Especially since that Asian kid was eliminated.  They're the ones you have to watch out for.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad!  Don't stereotype!

speaker: Martin
text: Not even a positive one?  Oh geez, what's happenin' in this country?  [_He heads off.  A young girl, one of the other contestants, walks past._]

speaker: Amanda
text: Hi, Freddie.

speaker: Freddie
text: Hi, Amanda.  [_He looks after her, a goofy grin on his face, as Frasier gets a suspicious look on his._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't let her distract you with her wiles, Son.  There'll be plenty of women once you win this thing, all right?  Okay, now, you were a little wobbly on that last word.  Just remember, when the root word is Greek, the "uh" sound is made with the letter "Y".  [_Martin comes back behind him._]

speaker: Frasier
text: So far, all the sneaky ones have had Greek roots.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, so it's okay for you to stereotype!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh...

speaker: Freddie
text: Dad, we've run over this a million times.  I got it.  [_to Martin_]  Where'd you get the soda?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, c'mon, I'll show you.  [_He leads Freddie outside, a man walks up to Frasier._]

speaker: John
text: Hey, hi there.  John Clayton.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hi.  [_They shake._]

speaker: John
text: My son, he's one of the finalists.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, nice to meet you.  Frasier Crane, I'm Frederick's dad. You've got a great little speller there.

speaker: John
text: Ah, yeah.  You too.  First year, I take it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh-huh.

speaker: John
text: Look, let me give you a little advice:  watch out for some of the parents.  They can be kinda cutthroat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thanks for the tip.

speaker: John
text: Yeah, no problem.  So, you and Freddie, you work on all the usuals, roots, suffixes, prefixes?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes all of that.

speaker: John
text: Good, good.  How about attitude?  Breathing, endurance...

speaker: Frasier
text: Sure, sure.  Endurance?

speaker: John
text: Excuse me.  [_He hurries over to his wife._]

speaker: John
text: Betsy!  The Crane kid's got no legs!  [_Dr. Gaston returns to the podium._]

speaker: Gaston
text: All right, we're ready to resume.  [_The contestants come back on stage and the girl steps to the microphone._]

speaker: Gaston
text: Amanda Abrams.  Amanda, your word is "milieu".

speaker: Amanda
text: "Milieu", M-I-L-L-I-E-U,  "milieu".  [_The buzzer sounds and Amanda walks off the stage.  Frasier gleefully turns to Martin._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Won't be long now.  [_He smiles confidently.  Fade out._]   **41 WORDS LATER** [_Fade in.  The competition is continuing, with the Freddie  and Warren Clayton standing side by side._]

speaker: Freddie
text: "Syllepsis", S-Y-L-L-E-P-S-I-S, "syllepsis".

speaker: Gaston
text: Warren Clayton, "resipiscence".

speaker: Warren
text: R-E-C-I-P-I-S-C-E-N-C-E, "resipiscence".  [_The buzzer sounds._]

speaker: Gaston
text: I'm sorry, but that's incorrect.  [_Warren walks off the stage._]

speaker: Gaston
text: If Frederick Crane gets the next word, he will be the National Champion.  Frederick, your word is "hermeneutic".

speaker: Freddie
text: Um, may I have a definition?  [_Frasier and Martin look at each other in alarm._]

speaker: Gaston
text: Interpretive or explanatory.

speaker: Freddie
text: "Hermeneutic", H-E-R-M-E-N-E-U-T-I-C, "hermeneutic".  [_As he's been spelling the word, Frasier has been tensing up and spelling silently along with him._]

speaker: Gaston
text: We have a new National Champion!  Frederick Crane!  [_Frasier and Martin cheer.  Frasier runs up to the stage as a woman hands Freddie the trophy._]

speaker: Gaston
text: Congratulations son.  [_Frasier smiles and puts his arm around the woman behind Freddie to pose for the pictures.  Fade out._]   **ACTUALLY, THE LETTER 'Y' ISN'T THAT FRIENDLY** [_Fade in.  Everyone is gathered around Freddie on the couch._]

speaker: Daphne
text: When you were spelling that last word, I thought I was going to have a heart attack.

speaker: Roz
text: Weren't you scared?

speaker: Freddie
text: A little, but then I just kinda relaxed.

speaker: Frasier
text: THAT is your spelling stance working for you.  Bend at the knees - spell with ease.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, this calls for a toast.  Is it all right if he has a little C-H-A-M-P-A-G...

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, he's the best speller in the country.

speaker: Daphne
text: So I should get the good stuff?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: You should be very proud of your accomplishment, Freddie. Just keep it in perspective.  And don't forget the twenty six little friends who got you here.  [_Martin comes in from the kitchen and goes to his chair._]

speaker: Martin
text: Gather 'round, everybody, almost time for ESPN to air Freddie's interview.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's right!  [_He grabs the remote and turns on the TV.  He then stands there, confused._]

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I have no idea where ESPN is.  [_He hands it to Martin, who takes it and changes the channel.  Roz sits in a dining chair._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks Dad.

speaker: Roz
text: See, I told you that penny would bring him good luck.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sitting_]  Oh, well, actually, Roz, I never even gave it to him.  See, with all of Freddie's hard work and dedication, inspired coaching...he had no need for your superstitious talisman.  [_The doorbell rings, Frasier goes to answer it._]

speaker: Roz
text: It's just a gesture.  I mean, I found it at the railroad track, not some enchanted wood.  [_Frasier opens the door to reveal Dr. Gaston from the competition._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well, what a surprise, please come in.  Everyone, this is Doctor Bernard Gaston from the spelling bee.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, hi, Doc.

speaker: Frasier
text: Lovely of you to join us in our little celebration.  Can I get you some refreshment?

speaker: Gaston
text: Unfortunately, this is not a pleasure visit.  I must inform you that there has been an accusation of cheating.

speaker: Martin
text: Not the Asian kid!  [_Everyone glares at him._]

speaker: Martin
text: What?  I said NOT the Asian kid.  Would somebody tell me the rules?

speaker: Frasier
text: Whoever the culprit is, we have no wish to soil this noble event by filing a formal protest.  We're certainly happy with the way things turned out.

speaker: Gaston
text: I'm afraid it's Frederick who's been accused of cheating.  [_Frasier gasps._]

speaker: Freddie
text: What!?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know what kind of a sick joke you're playing, but my son is no cheater!

speaker: Martin
text: I was there, I didn't see anything.

speaker: Gaston
text: Well we have evidence to the contrary.  Mr. and Mrs. Clayton noticed an anomaly on the tape while they were making Warren watch it.

speaker: Frasier
text: What sort of an anomaly?

speaker: Gaston
text: You were clearly mouthing the letters as Frederick spelled the last word, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: I did no such thing!

speaker: Gaston
text: We have it on the tape.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, if I did, it certainly wasn't a conscious act.  It was like singing along at a concert.  You know, I remember being admonished by the ushers for joining in a particularly intense performance of Das Lieb und der Uder!  [_Freddie gets up._]

speaker: Freddie
text: I wasn't even looking at him!

speaker: Gaston
text: Let's not make this any more painful than it already is.  The committee has reviewed the tape and decided to award the trophy to Warren Clayton.

speaker: Freddie
text: What?!  You can't do that!

speaker: Martin
text: This stinks!

speaker: Gaston
text: I'm sure you'd like to avoid embarrassment as much we would so we'll just say this was all due to a technicality.  That way, Frederick can keep his regional title and even attend the banquet tomorrow night for all the finalists.  [_He reaches over and picks the trophy up from the coffee table._]

speaker: Freddie
text: This isn't fair.

speaker: Gaston
text: I'm sorry, son.  I hope I'll see you at the dinner.  [_He leaves._]

speaker: Freddie
text: Thanks a lot, Dad.  [_He hurries off._]

speaker: Roz
text: You should have given him the penny.  [_Fade out._]  _Act 2  Scene 1 - Frasier's Apartment_  [_Fade in.  Martin is in his chair, Freddie is on the couch, playing a video game.  Frasier comes in the front door._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Great news!  I have just spoken to a lawyer who believes we have a case against the spelling bee officials.  Isn't that great?  [_Freddie keeps playing the game as Frasier hangs up his coat._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Frederick, look, I know how upset you are.  I'm so sorry. Frederick, aren't you going to say something?  [_Freddie puts down the controller._]

speaker: Freddie
text: I talked to Mom today.  [_He heads for the kitchen._]

speaker: Frasier
text: You're a bigger man than I am.

speaker: Freddie
text: That's what she said.  [_He exits._]

speaker: Frasier
text: I've really done it this time, haven't I?  I feel terrible. He just hates me.

speaker: Martin
text: No, he's disappointed, that's all.

speaker: Frasier
text: Still, he knows that if I made a mistake it was only because I wanted him to win so badly.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, he'll get over it.  Remember when you were thirteen, you had that science project?  I came in your room and sat on it? You forgave me.

speaker: Frasier
text: True.  Spent six months working on that project.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, my point is, accidents happen.  He'll come to see that.

speaker: Frasier
text: I suppose you're right.  Three perfectly good chairs in my room, you had to sit on my hybrid orchid.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, let's hope Freddie's as forgiving as you are.  [_Cut to - the kitchen.  Niles is cooking, Freddie gets the ice cream out._]

speaker: Niles
text: So, you going to go to that banquet tonight, Freddie?

speaker: Freddie
text: I don't think so.  It'll just be a bunch of people saying bad stuff about me.

speaker: Niles
text: None of which is true.

speaker: Freddie
text: But they think it is.  [_Niles gets a scoop and bowl for Freddie._]

speaker: Freddie
text: Uncle Niles, is it true that you walked out on the last word of the National Bee?

speaker: Niles
text: Now, where did you hear that?

speaker: Freddie
text: Dad and Grandpa.  They said you were one of the best.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, they exaggerate.

speaker: Freddie
text: They said you were just as good as somebody named Karek.

speaker: Niles
text: "Just as good"?  Funny.  Anyway, the story is true.  I never talked about it before, but I will.  Since you also have the gift.  Have a seat.  [_They sit down on the kitchen stools._]

speaker: Niles
text: I was a little younger than you.  I'd been winning numerous competitions, but I was obsessed with one thing and one thing only:  the National Championship.  The time finally came and there I was, standing on that stage, waiting for the judge to say the final word, and suddenly it happened.  It all clicked.  All the rules, "i before e", assimilations, etymologies, they all became one.  And then, became nothing. In that moment, I realized there was no word I couldn't spell.  Competitions didn't matter anymore because I was one with the higher truth that is spelling.  So when the judge said that last word, I just walked away.

speaker: Freddie
text: Didn't you care what people said?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, people said a lot of things that weren't true.  "He didn't know the word."  "He was scared."  "Mafia this..." No, it didn't bother me.  Because they couldn't take away what I knew in my heart.  You know how to spell, and it doesn't matter what anybody else thinks.  [_Freddie starts walking out._]

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, hey, don't you want your ice cream?

speaker: Freddie
text: No, I have a banquet to go to.  [_He exits.  Fade out._]   [_Fade in.  Freddie, Frasier and Niles come in and walk to their table. Amanda is there._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, here we are.

speaker: Freddie
text: Hi, Amanda.  [_She walks away without saying anything._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Never mind her, Freddie.  It's her problem, not yours.  You didn't do anything wrong.

speaker: Freddie
text: I know.  Neither did you.  Excuse me.  [_He gets up and walks out as Dr. Gaston steps to the podium._]

speaker: Gaston
text: Good evening.  I'd like to take this opportunity to welcome you to this year's annual Spell-abration.  Because of the irregularities with this year's event, this gathering has been renamed "The Unity Dinner" and is in honor of all the finalists.  [_There is polite applause, but Frasier looks shocked and leans across to Niles._]

speaker: Frasier
text: What the hell is that supposed to mean?  "Irregularities"?

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, Frasier, let it go.  [_John Clayton comes up._]

speaker: John
text: Crane, no hard feelings.  [_He offers his hand and Frasier shakes it._]

speaker: Frasier
text: No feelings at all.

speaker: John
text: Now, don't be like that.  You're not the first person tempted to get around the rules, you just got caught.

speaker: Frasier
text: I did not "get caught".

speaker: John
text: Well, cameras never lie and cheaters never prosper.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_rising_]  And you never shut up!

speaker: Niles
text: [_getting up_]  Frasier, Frasier, try to follow Frederick's example and carry ourselves with dignity.  [_A security guard comes in, dragging Freddie and Warren along. Frasier, Niles and John hurry over._]  Guard:  Where are your parents?

speaker: Niles
text: Freddie?

speaker: Frasier
text: What's going on? Guard:  I caught these two fighting in the men's room.

speaker: Warren
text: He punched me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is this true?

speaker: Freddie
text: He deserved it!

speaker: Niles
text: Why'd you do it, Freddie?

speaker: Freddie
text: He called my dad a cheater!

speaker: Frasier
text: You were defending me?

speaker: Niles
text: Where's your blazer?

speaker: Freddie
text: It's in the bathroom.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, dear.  If it's touched the floor, we'll have to destroy it.  [_He heads off._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Freddie, I want you to apologize to Warren right now.

speaker: John
text: Yes, and Warren, you apologize too.  Being a name-caller's almost as bad as being a cheater.

speaker: Frasier
text: I am NOT a cheater!  You are a thief.  My son is the true champion.

speaker: Warren
text: Yeah, when your dad's here to help you.

speaker: Freddie
text: Hey, I can out spell you anytime, anyplace!

speaker: Warren
text: Oh yeah?  How 'bout right now?!

speaker: John
text: Hold on Son, we don't have to prove anything.

speaker: Freddie
text: I can take you in five words!

speaker: Warren
text: Okay, you're on!  For the trophy!

speaker: John
text: Hey, we already have the trophy.  Crane, why don't you talk some sense into your boy, there?

speaker: Frasier
text: Freddie...

speaker: Freddie
text: Dad, I want to spell.

speaker: Frasier
text: What's the matter, John?  You scared?  [_There is a murmur in the crowd._]

speaker: John
text: For the trophy!

speaker: Gaston
text: We have already selected an official winner.  If you'd like to brawl, take it someplace else.

speaker: John
text: Let's take it outside!

speaker: Frasier
text: To the streets!  [_Everyone rushes out.  Fade to - the alley behind the hall._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Sudden death, Scrips-Howard rules!

speaker: John
text: Bring it on!  [_Niles comes out the door._]

speaker: Niles
text: People, stop please!  Look at yourselves.  This is wrong. What are words, after all, but a way to communicate, to bring us together?  But you, you're using them as weapons!  Now, we still have an opportunity to walk away from here as winners, and wouldn't that be the greatest Spell-abration of all?

speaker: Frasier
text: He's right, Son, let's go home.  [_They turn and head for the door with Niles._]

speaker: John
text: Yeah, we're all winners.  Except for the two cheaters!  [_The Crane boys stop, then collect themselves and continue._]

speaker: Warren
text: Hey, you know how to spell "loser"?  C-R-A-N-E.  [_Again, the Cranes halt a moment, then keep going._]

speaker: John
text: You don't have to worry about ever seeing him again, Son. Chances are he'll end up in a state school.  [_Freddie, Frasier and Niles whirl around, rage on their faces._]

speaker: Niles
text: How DARE you!  [_to Freddie_]  Can you take him?

speaker: Freddie
text: Yeah!

speaker: Niles
text: Then spell his ass off!  [_They rush back to the middle.  Frasier grabs the dictionary from a bystander.  Fade out._]
